fields.summary: Improper plexus javac compilation of generic java.lang.Enum definitions

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: The issue is not a bug
resolution.name: Not A Bug

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

comments.body: Still an issue... the workaround only worked until I had to pass the argument to another method that took Enum<? extends IEnumTest> from which point I receive the same error :(

It seems like Eclipse's JDT compiler is doing "something" that native Java5 does not do which allows it to support your generic Enums. (Just because something works in Eclipse does not mean that Maven is broken.)

Maven version: 2.0.8
Java version: 1.6.0_03
OS name: "windows xp" version: "5.1" arch: "x86" Family: "windows"

Using your zip file, I got a build failure since you've got EnumTestCase in both main and test. One fix is to change junit dep scope to "compile". The other is to delete the main instance.

After doing that, everything compiled and ran just fine.
Running org.test.EnumTestCase
PHASE: ONE
PHASE: TWO
PHASE: THREE
Tests run: 1, Failures: 0, Errors: 0, Skipped: 0, Time elapsed: 0.05 sec


Then, I changed my JAVA_HOME etc to 1.5.0_06:
Maven version: 2.0.8
Java version: 1.5.0_06
OS name: "windows xp" version: "5.1" arch: "x86" Family: "windows"

And immediately ran into your error:
[ERROR] BUILD FAILURE
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
[INFO] Compilation failure
C:\cvs_root\maven\plx-358\test-project\src\test\java\org\test\EnumTestCase.java:[15,80] incompatible types
found   : java.lang.Enum<? extends org.test.EnumTestCase.IEnumTest>
required: java.lang.Enum<? extends org.test.EnumTestCase.IEnumTest>


Then, I tried compiling using the JDK javac directly.
C:\cvs_root\maven\plx-358\test-project\src\test\java\org\test>javac -version
javac 1.5.0_06

C:\cvs_root\maven\plx-358\test-project\src\test\java\org\test>javac -cp "C:\Documents and Settings\WFay\.m2\repository\junit\junit\3.8.1\junit-3.8.1.jar" EnumTestCase.java
EnumTestCase.java:15: incompatible types
found   : java.lang.Enum<? extends org.test.EnumTestCase.IEnumTest>
required: java.lang.Enum<? extends org.test.EnumTestCase.IEnumTest>
                for (Enum<? extends IEnumTest> phase : enumTest.getEnumConstants()) {
                                                                                ^
1 error

And then tried Java6 directly:
C:\cvs_root\maven\plx-358\test-project\src\test\java\org\test>javac -version
javac 1.6.0_03

C:\cvs_root\maven\plx-358\test-project\src\test\java\org\test>javac -cp "C:\Documents and Settings\WFay\.m2\repository\junit\junit\3.8.1\junit-3.8.1.jar" EnumTestCase.java

Given all this, I'm pretty convinced there is something "special" happening in Eclipse's JDT compiler that makes your Enums work, and that native Java5 doesn't like them. Thus, this is not a bug in Maven or PLX.

Also wanted to mention that I can execute your EnumTestCase directly using Java6 with no problems (but obviously not Java5, since it won't even compile):

C:\cvs_root\maven\plx-358\test-project\src\test\java>java -cp ".;C:\Documents and Settings\WFay\.m2\repository\junit\junit\3.8.1\junit-3.8.1.jar" org.test.EnumTestCase
.PHASE: ONE
PHASE: TWO
PHASE: THREE

Time: 0.01

OK (1 test)
Please try updating jdk 1.5.0 to the latest version (1.5.0.13). There was a generics + enum bug in versions prior to 1.5.0.07 (or 1.5.0.08 maybe)
I wish I could update the to 1.5.0.13 but this is controlled through Apple Java Releases (AFAIK you cannot download jdk from sun).

Will, it seems like this isn't something Maven/Plexus can help you with. You'll have to wait for a newer Java5 release from Apple or perhaps install the OpenJDK-based Java6 (SoyLatte) instead.

If none of those will work and you are really motivated, you could probably add code to Plexus to support the JDT compiler directly...

AFAICS this is purely and completely a Sun javac bug. 1.5.0.13 fails, 1.6.0.03 works, executing a raw javac command directly. There are quite a few issues in the Sun bug database regarding buggy computation of generic type bounds in 1.5.0 javac. A workaround is to cast the return value of getEnumConstants() to the raw Enum[] type.

I'm working in the IntelliJ IDEA IDE, and I may have a related problem.

I have a simple enum defined in TransactionType.groovy

enum { DEPOSIT, WITHDRAW, TRANSFER }

The generated TransactionType.java file has this signature:

public class TransactionType extends java.lang.Enum<TransactionType> {}

Under my currently available compilers:
java version "1.5.0_14"
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.5.0_14-b03)
Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.5.0_14-b03, mixed mode, sharing)

java version "1.6.0_03"
Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.6.0_03-b05)
Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.6.0_03-b05, mixed mode, sharing)

Both generate the following error when compiling:
"classes cannot directly extend java.lang.Enum"

The Plexus "compilers" are merely wrappers/adapters around real compiler implementations from third-party vendors. Errors that result directly from the compiler implementor like parsing errors need to be reported to the respective vendor (Sun, Apple, whatever).

Using the following configuration compiles successfully (tested on XP). Without it results in the previously described compiler error:

{code}
<!-- Use the latest Eclipse JDT compiler rather than the default plexus compiler that causes issues when compiling generics (3.4.2.v_883_R34x from JBoss repo) -->
	<build>
		<plugins>
			<plugin>
				<groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
				<artifactId>maven-compiler-plugin</artifactId>
				<version>2.0.2</version>
				<configuration>
					<source>1.6</source>
					<target>1.6</target>
					<compilerVersion>1.6</compilerVersion>
					<encoding>UTF-8</encoding>
					<fork>true</fork>
					<executable>java -classpath ${env.M2_REPO}/org/eclipse/jdt/core/3.4.2.v_883_R34x/core-3.4.2.v_883_R34x.jar org.eclipse.jdt.internal.compiler.batch.Main -classpath rt.jar -sourcepath "src/main"</executable>
				</configuration>
				<dependencies>
					<dependency>
						<groupId>org.eclipse.jdt</groupId>
						<artifactId>core</artifactId>
						<version>3.4.2.v_883_R34x</version>
					</dependency>
				</dependencies>
			</plugin>
		</plugins>
	</build>
{code}
